title: BHP's British shareholders vote to stick with Minerals Council
text:
"Regardless of the percentage of the vote achieved today, we know that over 50 climate-aware investors with over $US10 trillion [$14.8 trillion] in assets under management have indicated support, either publicly or privately."

BHP chairman Ken MacKenzie told the AGM he saw BHP as a "force for good" within the trade bodies to which it belonged.

And CEO Andrew Mackenzie said BHP benefited from its participation in industry bodies, and tried to steer them towards constructive outcomes.

"Mining trade associations especially deserve our full engagement," Mr Mackenzie said.

"At a time of increased focus on local solidarity, protection and intervention in response to increased insecurity and global changes, it's our participation in industry associations which can contribute to the more global solutions also required for a more progressive world."

He referred to an industry taskforce he was leading that was considering how to make the sector's vehicle fleets greener and safer. "This typifies the vast bulk of the work of all the trade associations we join, and we work tirelessly to make sure this kind of work is their major and predominant role."

The ACCR had been looking to pull BHP out of not only the Minerals Council but also the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association, the Queensland Resources Council and NSW Minerals Council. The resolution was backed by tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes, several overseas pension funds and Australia's Vision Super.

Advertisement

Their argument was that the Minerals Council has advocated for new coal-fired power stations and funded pro-coal advertising on Facebook and in The Australian newspaper, as well as sharing key staff with pro-coal lobby group Coal21.

BHP in September recommended that shareholders vote against the resolution, but is reviewing its membership of all industry organisations. Mr MacKenzie told the AGM that BHP's similar reviews in the past had delivered tangible results.

Rio Tinto has previously threatened to quit the Minerals Council if it made statements contradicting the Paris Agreement.

The Minerals Council last week responded to the campaign by promising to issue an action plan next year to help address human-induced climate change and limit global warming in accordance with the Paris Agreement.

Former Labor minister Chris Schacht took the floor at the London AGM to advocate against the ACCR's motion.

"[BHP] has an enormous influence if it stays in the industry association," he said. "You can twist the arm [of other association members]. Every time that industry association says something against climate change, you should publicly disagree."

BHP's British shareholders meanwhile voted in favour of the company's new remuneration scheme that aligns executive pay with performance in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
description: The London leg of the mining giant's AGM rejects a push to sever links with trade bodies seen as lagging on climate change.
